hints_raw: Why does plugging in <math>x = 3</math> into the fraction not work? Maybe some factoring can help here.
question: 2 (a) ii
sols_html:
Notice that we cannot simply plug in \(x = 3\) as we will get \(B = 0/0\), an indeterminate form.

To evaluate this limit, factor the numerator and denominator of the fraction as much as possible:

\[\begin{aligned} B = \lim_{x \to 3}\frac{x^{2} - 2x - 3}{x^{2} - 3x} = \lim_{x \to 3}\frac{(x - 3)(x + 1)}{(x - 3)x}.\end{aligned}\]

Notice that there is a term that can be cancelled out from the numerator and denominator and rewrite the limit:

\[\begin{aligned} B = \lim_{x \to 3}\frac{x + 1}{x}.\end{aligned}\]

Using the properties of limits, we can now evaluate this limit by plugging in the value \(x = 3\)

\[\begin{aligned} B = \frac{\lim_{x \to 3} x + 1}{\lim_{x \to 3} x} = \frac{4}{3} \quad \rightarrow \quad {\color{blue}B =\frac{4}{3}}.\end{aligned}\]

B = \lim_{x \to 3}\frac{x^{2} - 2x - 3}{x^{2} - 3x} = \lim_{x \to 3}\frac{(x - 3)(x + 1)}{(x - 3)x}.
</math>

Notice that there is a term that can be cancelled out from the numerator and denominator and rewrite the limit:
:<math>
B = \lim_{x \to 3}\frac{x + 1}{x}.

Using the properties of limits, we can now evaluate this limit by plugging in the value <math>x = 3</math>
:<math>
B = \frac{\lim_{x \to 3} x + 1}{\lim_{x \to 3} x} = \frac{4}{3} \quad \rightarrow \quad {\color{blue}B = \frac{4}{3}}.
</math>
